== Uranium mining and milling ==
=== Canada === In 1942 thirty indigenous Dené men were recruited to mine uranium, locally known as "the money rock" for three dollars per day at the [[Port Radium]] mine. By 1998, 14 of these workers had died of lung, colon and kidney cancers, according to the North West Territory's Cancer Registry. The Dené were not told of the hazards of mining uranium, and breathed radioactive dust, slept on the ore, and ate fish from the tailings ponds. Ottawa was the world's largest supplier of uranium at that time, and the United States the biggest buyer, according to declassified U.S. documents. In subsequent decades, thousands of Native miners were not warned of the risks.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Nikiforuk|first1=Andrew|title=Echoes of the Atomic Age: Cancer kills fourteen aboriginal uranium workers|url=http://www.ccnr.org/deline_deaths.html|accessdate=13 December 2014|publisher=Calgary Herald|date=March 14, 1998}}</ref>
=== Namibia === [[File:Arandis Mine hochformat.jpg|thumb|Rössig open-pit uranium mine near [[Arandis, Namibia]]]]
Namibia's [[Rössing Uranium Mine]] is the longest-operating open-pit uranium mine, and one of the largest in the world. The company is owned and operated by [[Rio Tinto Group|Rio Tinto]], one of the world's largest mining groups, and Rössing Uranium Limited. The uranium mill tailings dam has been leaking for a number of years, and on January 17, 2014, a catastrophic structural failure of a leach tank caused a major spill.<ref>{{cite web|last=WISE Uranium Project|title=Issues at Rössing Uranium Mine, Namibia|url=http://www.wise-uranium.org/umoproe.html|publisher=World Information Service on Energy, Uranium Project|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref> The France-based laboratory, Commission de Recherche et d'Information Independentantes sur la Radioactivite (CRIIAD) reported elevated levels of radioactive materials in the area surrounding the mine.<ref>{{cite web|last=Commission de Recherche et d'Information Indépendantes sur la Radioactivité|title=Preliminary results of CRIIRAD radiation monitoring near uranium mines in Namibia|url=http://www.criirad.org/actualites/dossier2012/namibie/CRIIRAD-namibia-press.pdf|work=April 11, 2012|publisher=CRIIAD|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Commission de Recherche et d'Information Indépendantes sur la Radioactivité|title=CRIIRAD Preliminary Report No. 12-32b Preliminary results of radiation monitoring near uranium mines in Namibia|url=http://www.criirad.org/actualites/dossier2012/namibie/CRIIRAD-namibia-prelim.pdf|work=April 5, 2012|publisher=CRIIRAD EJOLT Project|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref>
There have been numerous reports published on labor and human rights conditions at the mine.<ref>{{cite web|last=SOMO|title=Uranium workers Namibia unaware of severe health risks|url=http://somo.nl/news-en/uranium-workers-namibia-unaware-of-severe-health-risks|work=May 12, 2009|publisher=SOMO, Netherlands|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref> Workers were not informed of the dangers of working with radioactive materials and the health effects thereof. The Director of Labor Resource and Research Institute (LaRRI), Hilma Shindondola-Mote, mine employees asserted that Rössing did not provide them with explanation of health problems from exposure to uranium.<ref>{{cite web|last=Labor Resource and Research Institute|title=Namibian workers in times of uncertainty: The Labour Movement 20 years after independence|url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B-h_z2Ab5OhDa2JMQTA1SEVPX2c/edit?pli=1|work=2009|publisher=LaRRI|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=LaRRI|title=Our Work: Labour Resource and Research Institute|url=http://larri-namibia.org/our-work/|work=April 25, 2013|publisher=LaRII|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Shinbdondola-Mote|first=Hilma|title=Uranium mining in Namibia: The mystery behind 'low level radiation'|url=https://docs.google.com/file/d/0B-h_z2Ab5OhDZEpjWDlaN1paek0/edit?pli=1|work=January, 2009|publisher=Labor Resource and Research Institute (LaRRI)|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref>
===Malawi=== At the open cut [[Kayelekera mine|Kayelekera uranium mine]] near Karonga, Malawi (Africa), a mine employee, Khwima Phiri, was killed on July 20, 2013. He was struck in the chest and killed while inflating a wheel.<ref>{{cite web|title=Malawian dies on duty at Kayelekera Uranium Mine in Karonga|url=http://www.nyasatimes.com/2013/07/31/malawian-dies-on-duty-at-kayelekera-uranium-mine-in-karonga/|website=Nyasa Times|publisher=Nyasatimes.com|accessdate=17 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204063449/http://www.nyasatimes.com/2013/07/31/malawian-dies-on-duty-at-kayelekera-uranium-mine-in-karonga/|archivedate=4 February 2015|df=}}</ref> There have been allegations of radiation-induced diseases among the mine workers and nearby residents. The Malawi government has been unable to verify these, stating that the absence of monitoring equipment. On June 19, 2011 a truck at the mine caught fire, killing the driver. On September 23, 2010, workers were ordered to work despite the fact that the mine could not provide them with dust masks to protect them against radioactive materials.<ref>{{cite web|last1=WISE|title=Issues at Operating Uranium Mines and Mills - Africa|url=http://www.wise-uranium.org/umopafr.html#LANGERH|website=WISE Uranium Project|publisher=World Information Service on Energy|accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=WISE|title=Regulatory Issues - Africa|url=http://www.wise-uranium.org/uregafr.html#MW|website=WISE Uranium Project|publisher=World Information Service on Energy|accessdate=17 May 2015}}</ref>
=== New Zealand and Australia === The American and British demand for large quantities of uranium to use in nuclear weapons initiated New Zealand's uranium survey during WWII. In 1944 in Wellington, geologists and physicists assembled two exploration teams to survey South Island, particularly the granite deposits and black beach sand areas. In 1945, Fiordland, Milford Sound, Nancy Sound and other locations were surveyed, resulting in the December 7, 1945 NZ Atomic Energy Act granting full ownership of any discovered radioactive elements - however not to the indigenous peoples whose ancestral lands contained these materials.<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Ara: Encyclopedia of New Zealand|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/radioactive-minerals/page-1|publisher=Government of New Zealand|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> In 1955, another rich uranium deposit was discovered by prospectors Frederick Cassin and Charles Jacobsen. In the following years prospectors traveled through rainforests and other terrain with Geiger counters, jackhammers and drills.<ref>{{cite web|title=Te Ara: Encyclopedia of New Zealand|url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/radioactive-minerals/page-3|publisher=Government of New Zealand|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref> These workers were exposed to unsafe levels of radiation through exposure to and inhalation of dust. In Australia, uranium mining was no less unrestrained than in New Zealand. At the Nabarlek, Rum Jungle, Hunter's Hill, Rockhole and Moline mines, gamma radiation exceeded safe levels by 50% causing chronic health problems for miners and workers.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sovacool|first1=Benjamin K.|last2=Dworkin|first2=Michael H.|title=Global Energy Justice|date=September 2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|isbn=9781107665088|page=162|url=https://books.google.com/?id=G_hkBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA162&lpg=PA162&dq=new+zealand+uranium+mine+workers#v=onepage&q=new%20zealand%20uranium%20mine%20workers&f=false|accessdate=23 October 2014}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:Shiprock, New Mexico uranium mill aerial photo.png|thumb|Shiprock, New Mexico uranium mill aerial photo]]Between 1949 and 1989, over 4,000 uranium mines in the Four Corners region produced more than 225,000,000 tons of uranium ore. This activity affected a large number of Native American nations, including the Laguna, Navajo, Zuni, Southern Ute, Ute Mountain, Hopi, Acoma and other Pueblo cultures.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Pasternak|first1=Judy|title=Yellow Dirt: An American Story of a Poisoned Land and a People Betrayed|date=2010|publisher=Free Press a Division of Simon & Schuster|location=New York, NY|isbn=978-1-4165-9482-6}}</ref> Many of these peoples worked in the mines, mills and processing plants in New Mexico, Arizona, Utah and Colorado. These workers were not only poorly paid, they were seldom informed of dangers nor were they given appropriate protective gear. The government, mine owners, scientific, and health communities were all well aware of the hazards of working with radioactive materials at this time.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Johnston|first1=B.R.|last2=Dawson|first2=S.E.|last3=Madsen|first3=Gary E.|editor1-last=Johnston, ed|editor1-first=Barbara Rose|title=Uranium Mining and Milling: Navajo Experiences in the American Southwest|date=2007|publisher=School for Advanced Research Resident Scholar Books|location=Santa Fe, NM|isbn=978-1-930618-82-4|pages=97–115}}</ref> Due to the Cold War demand for increasingly destructive and powerful nuclear weapons, these laborers were both exposed to and brought home large amounts of radiation in the form of dust on their clothing and skin. Epidemiological studies of the families of these workers have shown increased incidents of radiation-induced cancers, miscarriages, cleft palates and other birth defects. The extent of these genetic effects on indigenous populations and the extent of DNA damage remains to be resolved.<ref>{{cite news|last=Frosh|first=Dan|title=Uranium Contamination Haunts Navajo Country|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/27/us/27navajo.html?_r=0|accessdate=31 March 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 26, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Johnston|first=Barbara Rose; Holly M. Barker; Marie I. Boutte; Susan Dawson; Paula Garb; Hugh Gusterson; Joshua Levin; Edward Liebow; Gary E. Madsen; David H. Price; Kathleen Purvis-Roberts; Theresa Satterfield; Edith Turner; Cynthia Werner|title=Half Lives & Half Truths: Confronting the Radioactive Legacies of the Cold War|year=2007|publisher=School for Advanced Research Press|location=Santa Fe, NM|isbn=1-930618-82-4|url=http://sarweb.org/?sar_press_half_lives_and_half_truths}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Brugge|first=Doug; Timothy Benally, Esther Yazzie-Lewis|title=The Navajo People and Uranium Mining|year=2007|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|location=Albuquerque, NM|isbn=0-8263-3779-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Brugge|first=Doug; Timothy Benally, Ester Yazzie Lewis|title=Uranium Mining on Navajo Indian Land|url=http://www.culturalsurvival.org/publications/cultural-survival-quarterly/united-states/uranium-mining-navajo-indian-land|work=Partnering with Indigenous Peoples to Defend their Lands, Languages and Cultures|publisher=Cultural Survival.org|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Jung|first=Carrie|title=Navajo Nation Opposes Uranium Mine on Sacred Site in New Mexico|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2013/12/21/navajo-nation-opposesuraniummineonsacredsiteinnewmexico.html|publisher=Al Jazerra|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Laramee|first=Eve Andree|title=Tracking Our Nuclear Legacy: Now we are all sons of bitches|url=http://weadartists.org/tracking-our-atomic-legacy|work=2012|publisher=WEAD: Women Environmental Artist Directory|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> Uranium mining on the Navajo reservation continues to be a disputed issue as former Navajo mine workers and their families continue to suffer from health problems.<ref>{{cite news|last=Reese|first=April|title=Navajo Group to Take Uranium Mine Challenge to Human Rights Commission|url=https://www.nytimes.com/gwire/2011/05/12/12greenwire-navajo-group-to-take-uranium-mine-challenge-to-33718.html?pagewanted=all|accessdate=21 April 2014|newspaper=The New York Times|date=May 12, 2011}}</ref>{{Main|Uranium mining and the Navajo people}}
==Asian nuclear industry==
===India=== * In March 1993 at India's [[Narora Atomic Power Station|Narora reactor]] an accident occurred in which two blades broke off a steam turbine leading to a hydrogen leak, hydrogen fire and oil fire. At this time India's Atomic Energy Commission and Department of Atomic Energy (DAE) were not required to "reveal the health record of workers" nor did the DAE "monitor the health of temporary workers" nor "reveal the quantity of radioactive substances released into the environment by accidents."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sweet|first1=Bill|title=Weakness of Indian Nuclear Regulation Manifest in Reactor Accident|url=http://spectrum.ieee.org/energywise/energy/nuclear/weakness-of-indian-nuclear-regulation-manifest-in-reactor-accident|website=IEEE Spectrum|publisher=Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> * In May, 2014, six contract workers were injured at the [[Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant]] in Tamil Nadu, India, and hospitalized for burns received during repair work.<ref>{{cite news|title=Workers injured in Indian nuclear accident|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia/2014/05/workers-injured-indian-nuclear-accident-201451413582226900.html|accessdate=26 October 2014|agency=Aljazeera|date=May 14, 2014}}</ref> In March 2014, a contract worker was killed and two injured during the construction of a nuclear submarine at the ship building town of Visakhapatnam.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Agence France-Presse|title=One Worker Killed in Indian Nuclear Sub Accident|url=http://www.defensenews.com/article/20140310/DEFREG03/303100018/One-Worker-Killed-Indian-Nuclear-Sub-Accident|publisher=Defense News, a Gannett company|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref>
=== South Korea === * Twenty two workers were exposed to radiation at the Wolsung nuclear power plant, near Seoul, North Korea on October 5, 1999, when 45 liters of [[heavy water]] leaked.<ref>{{cite web|title=World: Asia-Pacific Accident at South Korea nuclear plant|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/465858.stm|website=BBC News|publisher=BBC|accessdate=26 October 2014}}</ref> * On December 26, 2014, three workers at the new Shin Kori nuclear power plant died of a suspected nitrogen gas leak.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Shankar|first1=Sneha|title=Three Workers At South Korean Nuclear Power Plant Die Of Suspected Gas Leak|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/three-workers-south-korean-nuclear-power-plant-die-suspected-gas-leak-1767462|accessdate=27 December 2014|agency=AP|publisher=International Business TImes|date=December 26, 2014}}</ref> The accident occurred after a series of threats by hackers claiming they can remotely control nuclear power plants.<ref>{{cite news|title=3 SKorea workers die at nuke plant construction site|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/d6e0d7b27c19487d9511de2a201443ff/3-skorea-workers-die-nuke-plant-construction-site|accessdate=27 December 2014|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Associated Press|date=December 26, 2014}}</ref>
=== Japan ===
==== Fukushima ==== {{Main|Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} [[File:Fukushima I NPP 1975.jpg|thumb|Fukushima I NPP 1975]][[File:Fukushima I reactor units 3 and 4 by Digital Globe.jpg|thumb|Fukushima I reactor units 3 and 4 by Digital Globe]] Following a large earthquake and tsunami on March 11, 2011 three nuclear reactors melted-down at the TEPCO Fukushima Daiichi power station in Japan.<ref>{{cite news|last1=International Atomic Energy Agency|title=IAEA International Fact Finding Expert Mission of the Fukushima Dai-ichi NPP Accident Following the Great East Japan Earthquake and Tsunami|url=http://www-pub.iaea.org/MTCD/meetings/PDFplus/2011/cn200/documentation/cn200_Final-Fukushima-Mission_Report.pdf|accessdate=23 August 2014|work=Team Leaders: Michael William Weightman, Health and Safety Executive, Office for Nuclear Regulation, United Kingdom and Philippe Jamet, Autorité de Surete Nucléaire, France|agency=IAEA Mission Report, Division of Nuclear Installation Safety, Department of Nuclear Safety and Security|issue=May 24 - June 2, 2011|publisher=IAEA|date=2011}}</ref> Despite TEPCO's ongoing efforts to stabilize, decommission, decontaminate and contain the radioactive materials, many workers have been exposed to significant doses of radiation.<ref>{{cite news|last=NBC News Wire Reports|title=Worker at Japan's tsunami-hit Fukushima nuclear plant: Firm sent crews into danger|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/11/01/14848483-worker-at-japans-tsunami-hit-fukushima-nuclear-plant-firm-sent-crews-into-danger?lite|accessdate=7 April 2014|newspaper=NBC World News|date=November 1, 2012}}</ref> Both skilled and unskilled laborers work on the extensive clean-up crew, many of those involved in the most dangerous work are on short contracts.<ref>{{cite web|title=Fukushima brings exploitation of nuclear power plants to light|url=http://www.ad.nl/ad/nl/1013/Buitenland/article/detail/2893265/2011/09/06/Fukushima-brengt-uitbuiting-in-kerncentrales-aan-het-licht.dhtml|work=Fukushima brengt uitbuiting in kerncentrales aan het licht|publisher=AD.nl|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hoffman|first=Russell D.|title=Fukishima's Suicide Squads|url=http://www.counterpunch.org/hoffman04042011.html|publisher=Counterpunch|accessdate=5 April 2014}}</ref> These "nuclear gypsies" or "jumpers" are often recruited from day labor sites across Japan.<ref>{{cite news|last=Glionna|first=John M.|title=Japan's 'nuclear gypsies' face radioactive peril at power plants|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/dec/04/world/la-fg-japan-nuclear-gypsies-20111204|accessdate=5 April 2014|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=December 4, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Hecht|first=Gabrielle|title=Nuclear Janitors: Contract Workers at the Fukushima Reactors and Beyond|journal=The Asia-Pacific Journal|date=January 14, 2013|volume=11|issue=1|url=http://www.japanfocus.org/-gabrielle-hecht/3880|accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref>
Contract labor in the nuclear industry is not new.<ref>{{cite web|last=Miura|first=Nagamitsu|title=Genpatsu Gypsies: The Hidden Tragedies of Japan's Nuclear Labor Force|url=http://www.jca.apc.org/web-news/corpwatch-jp/96.html|publisher=Tsuda College, Tokyo, Japan|accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> Years prior to the Fukushima accident, the ''Los Angeles Times'' reported in 1999 that nearly 90% of Japanese nuclear power plant workers were subcontracted to perform the most hazardous jobs. Included in the report is the incident at the Tokaimura JCO Co. nuclear plant, 80 miles north of Tokyo, where 150 workers were exposed to radiation, including one fatality, based on the Japan Nuclear Safety Commission report. In 1999, the ''Los Angeles Times'' reported that nearly 90% of Japanese nuclear power plant workers were subcontracted to perform the most hazardous jobs.<ref>{{cite news|last=Efron|first=Sonni|title=System of Disposable Laborers|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/dec/30/news/mn-49042|accessdate=20 April 2014|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=December 30, 1999|at=Column One}}</ref> In 2010, the year before the Fukushima accident, eight-eight percent of Japan's nuclear workforce of 83,000 workers were contracted, not full-time workers. The Tokyo-based Citizens' Nuclear Information Center reported that temporary workers absorbed 16 times higher levels of radiation than regular TEPCO employees.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hernandez-Ceballos|first=M.A.|author2=G.H. Hong|author3=R.L. Lozano|author4=Y.I. Kim|author5=H.M. Lee|author6=S.H. Kim b|author7=S.-W. Yeh|author8=J.P. Bolívar|author9=M. No You Can't|journal=The Economist|date=October 8, 2012|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/banyan/2012/10/japans-nuclear-disaster?fsrc=nlw%7Cnewe%7C10-8-2012%7C3710276%7C35457804%7CNA}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Global Voices|title=Japan: A Nuclear Gypsy's Tale|url=http://enformable.com/2011/08/nuclear-gypsy-from-hamaoka-nuclear-power-plant-relates-experiences/|publisher=Global Voices|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref> Keeping the cleanup crew fully staffed, 24 hours per day, on 12-hour shifts, rotating every three days is a physical and logistical challenge to an emergency that will sustain for decades during which an ongoing stream of workers is required.<ref name="Time, by Krista Mahr, March 31, 2011 http://globalspin.blogs.time.com/2011/03/31/whats-in-store-for-japan's-embattled-nuclear-workers/">{{cite magazine|last=Mahr|first=Krista|title=What's in Store for Japan's Embattled Nuclear Workers?|magazine=TIME Magazine|date=March 31, 2011}}</ref> In a lecture given May 3, 2011 to the All Freeter's Union in Tokyo by the photographer Kenji Higuchi, "The Truth of the Fukushima 50", he cites TEPCO's lack of responsible oversight. of the Fukushima 50|url=https://www.academia.edu/678331/Kenji_Higuchi_The_Truth_of_the_Fukushima_50_|publisher=Academia.edu|accessdate=7 April 2014}}</ref> The few workers who have come forward, such
